original_title: خيانة كاملة: سيرة نسليهان بنت الباشا
cover:
Finally, when Yusef finished, he brought to the Basha a small pottery vessel sealed with lead and dark wax, red colored and saturated with blue. He requested the Basha that a virgin girl bury that pot under a slab in the middle of the palace at a depth of two meters.  

The women of the palace were enthusiastic about everything Yusef was doing. Farlan, Assia, and Bahri had magical powers, which they concealed very discreetly from the Basha. Nasli did not miss any of Yusef's movements, not out of curiosity about what he was doing, but for another reason:  that thing that you cannot deny, you feel it, though you cannot identify, or explain it.  

Yes, that thing happened, the hidden river ran between them, that water that Youssef always wished to avoid it forever, he wanted to escape from her at the exact moment his eyes met hers. Yusef predicted the abilities of the three women of the palace, as he paid attention to one of those hieroglyphs carved with precision over the door of Sitt Neslihan’s room.
title: Lina Hawyan Al-Hasan
authorDetails:
Lina Hawyan Al-Hasan, Syrian novelist (1974- )

She is the first to write about the unknown world of the desert of the Middle East. Lina is the
daughter of this desert, of its myths and its incredible stories, the same ones that have fascinated
orientalists. In addition, she opened the intimate rooms of the palaces and houses of the city of
Damascus, Aleppo and Antioch to tell us stories about the different populations and religions that
coexisted in the Middle East: Middle Eastern Jews in the early 20th century, the tragedy of the
Armenians, the migration of the Circassians, and the arrival of those fleeing the Bolshevik Revolution
to the city of Aleppo, as well as the Kurds in northern Syria.

The hybridity of her subjects finds its primary source in her extraordinary nomadic life, since her
childhood. Lina was born into a family belonging to a desert tribal community in the desert of the
Levant, and at the same time she lived and moved with her family in different cities and places
because of her father's work as an army officer.
She was born in an old Aleppo mansion that was turned into rented rooms in the seventies, in which
Muslims, Christians and Jews live side by side. Then she lived in the city of Latakia, on the seashore,
where there is a multi-sectarian city. At the same time, she maintained her close relationship with
the Syrian desert and her relatives who live a nomadic life. She lived for two years in the desert with
her grandmother and travelled with her. They lived in a tent woven from goat hair and a flock of
sheep.
She moved after into a house in the middle of a fish farm that used to belong to the army. And she
lived among water snakes and turtles, and carried with her different memories as she moved to the
city of Damascus and lived her adolescence there, studying philosophy and working in cultural
journalism. In 2011, she moved to Beirut because of the Syrian war and devoted herself entirely to
writing. She became one of the most important Arab writers, and her works were very popular.

The works of the novelist Lina Houyan Al-Hassan dealt with the worlds of the deserts of the Middle
East, and she is the first to write about it in the novel Sultans of Sand (2009, a biography of the most
famous beauties of the Levant, between 1880 and 1950), Men and Tribes (2015, a documentary
about the tribal history of the Syrian desert).
After that, her works followed on the Damascene society, and dealt with the secrets of Damascene
women, such as the novel A whole Betrayal (2022, the story of the last Damascene harem and the
biography of the first woman who drove a car in Syria), and Nazik Khanum (2020, the story of a
Damascene model who lived in Paris in (the seventies). She wrote Antioch and the Kings of the
Shadow, a novel about the city of Aleppo before Antioch was annexed to Turkey (2021, the story of
a group of women who underwent through major transformations that witnessed the transition
from feudalism to the beginnings of the Modern State, and its impact on their ideas and lives). The
Heel of the fairy (2022, a diary of a journey to the north-east of Syria, an excursion into the myths
and monuments of the places).

Awards and prices

The Heel of the fairy: Ibn Battuta Prize in 2022 for Travel Literature.
Antioch and the Kings of the Shadow: the long list of the Sheikh Zayed Book Award in 2021.
The Ruler of the Two Citadels: the long list of the Man Booker Prize.

Diamonds and Women: the short list of the Man Booker Prize.

title: David Daoud
cover:
The audacious Nazik, who wears a mini-jub and drinks whiskey without
showing signs of drunkenness, knows that she was a very beautiful being who, of
course, was not admired by women. When she returned to Damascus, she had
recently dyed her hair blonde, revealing the charms of a taut muscular body,
kissed slightly by the sun. Nazik’s rivals justified the secret of her grace by saying,
“She did not give birth to children.”
Nazik was returning for the first time to Damascus after twenty years, preceded
by various and startling rumors about her ambiguous and tumultuous past in
Paris. Some used to pass clippings from French newspapers showing a young girl
who looked a lot like her, displaying different outfits, some wearing furs and
others wearing bathing suits. There are pictures of her appearing almost naked,
carrying a crocodile-skin bag.
author: Lina Hawyan Al-Hasan
details:
Born in Lebanon in 1970, David Daoud lives and works in the Vexin, and exhibits notably between
Paris, Belgium and Lebanon.
David began drawing and painting at a very young age. Based in Paris, he continued his studies at the
Ecole Supérieure Nationale des Arts Décoratifs de Paris. He perfected his technique with his mentor,
the famous sculptor Charles Auffret, himself a disciple of Auguste Rodin.

An artist, painter, designer, sculptor, hard worker, David Daoud, draws his inspiration from nature
and Cave Art. He is inhabited by a “Dream of the absolute”, one of those artists who does not inhabit
the present, of these dreamers who escape the violence and chaos of the world by taking refuge in
their imaginary universe.
In music, poetry, nature too... An old-fashioned artist – in the positive sense of the term – who
draws his inspiration from the sources of cave art, the great masters of painting, pieces from the
repertoire German Romanticism, Handel's oratorios, Baudelairian poems and even the
contemplation of nature.
Here, a reference to ancient frescoes, there, graphic figures evocative of primitive scenes, further,
sets of characters drawn with a brush removed in the style of Rembrandt. A mixture of inspirations
and influences which gives his paintings a timeless aesthetic, between contemporary touches and
classic breath.
In the symbolist vein, flirting with impressionism, the painter expresses himself mainly in large
format. His favourite themes relate to the passing of time: exile, travel, distance, nostalgia, absence
and eternity.
The artist has exhibited in numerous galleries, museums and cultural sites in France, Belgium and
Lebanon.
His works are present in the permanent collection of the Institut du Monde Arabe (Paris) and
Prehistorique Museum of Beyrouth (Liban).
In 2018, Ibrahim Maalouf chose one of his works for the cover of his album ‘Levantine Symphony’.
